Which version do I choose?

IIS
If you are using PHP as FastCGI with IIS you should use the Non-Thread Safe (NTS) versions of PHP.

Apache
Please use the Apache builds provided by Apache Lounge. They provide VC14, VC15 and VS16 builds of Apache for x86 and x64. We use their binaries to build the Apache SAPIs.

With Apache you have to use the Thread Safe (TS) versions of PHP.

VC14, VC15 & VS16
More recent versions of PHP are built with VC14, VC15 or VS16 (Visual Studio 2015, 2017 or 2019 compiler respectively) and include improvements in performance and stability.

  • The VC14, VC15 and VS16 builds require to have the Visual C++ Redistributable for Visual Studio 2015-2019 x64 or x86 installed

entry.title: å¦‚ä½•ï¼ˆä¸é è¿æ°”ï¼‰å˜å¾—å¯Œæœ‰
entry.content:
æ ¹æ®ä¸€äº›æœ‹å‹çš„æ„è§ï¼Œåšä¸€ä¸‹ä¸­è‹±æ–‡å¯¹ç…§

æœ€è¿‘ä¸¤å¤©ï¼ŒAngelListçš„CEOï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¹Ÿæ˜¯Twitterçš„å¤©ä½¿æŠ•èµ„äººNavalåœ¨Twitterä¸Šçš„40æ¡è‡´å¯Œç»æ¨å¼•èµ·äº†ä¸€é˜µæ¨æ–‡é£æš´ï¼Œç›®å‰è¿™äº›æ¨æ–‡å·²ç»è¢«è½¬è¯‘æˆäº†æ•°åç§è¯­è¨€ï¼Œå¹¶å¯èƒ½å·²ç»è¢«30%ä»¥ä¸Šçš„Twitteræ´»è·ƒç”¨æˆ·çœ‹åˆ°äº†ã€‚ç»è¿‡Navalçš„åŒæ„ï¼Œæˆ‘æŠŠä»–è½¬è¯‘æˆäº†ä¸­æ–‡ï¼Œæ”¾åœ¨äº†æ¨ä¸Šï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ¨ç‰¹ä¸èƒ½ç¼–è¾‘å’Œä¿®è®¢ï¼Œè€Œæœ‰äº›é”™åˆ«å­—å’Œç¿»è¯‘å€¼å¾—æ¨æ•²ä¿®è®¢ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¹Ÿä¸€å¹¶æ”¾åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œæ¬¢è¿å¤§å®¶ç»™å‡ºå»ºè®®ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¼šæ ¹æ®å»ºè®®åšæ›´é€‚å½“çš„ä¿®è®¢ã€‚

Twitterè‹±æ–‡åŸé“¾æ¥åœ¨æ­¤

æˆ‘åœ¨æ¨ä¸Šçš„ä¸­æ–‡é“¾æ¥åœ¨æ­¤

ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯åŸæ–‡å’Œè¯‘æ–‡å…¨æ–‡

How to Get Rich (without getting lucky):

å¦‚ä½•ï¼ˆä¸é è¿æ°”ï¼‰å˜å¾—å¯Œæœ‰:

Seek wealth, not money or status. Wealth is having assets that earn while you sleep. Money is how we transfer time and wealth. Status is your place in the social hierarchy.

å¯»æ±‚è´¢å¯Œï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯é’±æˆ–è€…èº«ä»½ã€‚è´¢å¯Œæ˜¯æ‹¥æœ‰ä½ åœ¨ç¡è§‰çš„æ—¶å€™éƒ½èƒ½æŒ£é’±çš„èµ„äº§ã€‚é’±æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨æ¥è½¬ç§»æ—¶é—´å’Œè´¢å¯Œçš„ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚èº«ä»½æ˜¯ä½ åœ¨ç¤¾ä¼šå±‚çº§ä¸­æ‰€å¤„çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚

Understand that ethical wealth creation is possible. If you secretly despise wealth, it will elude you.

æ‡‚å¾—åˆ›é€ é“å¾·çš„è´¢å¯Œæ˜¯å¯èƒ½çš„ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ æš—åœ°é‡Œè½»è§†è´¢å¯Œï¼Œè´¢å¯Œå°±ä¼šèº²ç€ä½ ã€‚

Ignore people playing status games. They gain status by attacking people playing wealth creation games.

å¿½è§†é‚£äº›ç©èº«ä»½æ¸¸æˆçš„äººã€‚ä»–ä»¬é€šè¿‡æ”»å‡»ç©è´¢å¯Œåˆ›é€ æ¸¸æˆçš„äººæ¥è·å¾—â€œèº«ä»½â€ã€‚

Youâ€™re not going to get rich renting out your time. You must own equityâ€Šâ€”â€Ša piece of a businessâ€Šâ€”â€Što gain your financial freedom.

ä½ ä¸ä¼šé€šè¿‡å‡ºç§Ÿä½ çš„æ—¶é—´å˜å¾—å¯Œæœ‰ã€‚ä½ å¿…é¡»æ‹¥æœ‰èµ„äº§â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€” ä¸€ä¸ªç”Ÿæ„çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€” æ¥æ”¶è·ä½ çš„è´¢åŠ¡è‡ªç”±ã€‚

You will get rich by giving society what it wants but does not yet know how to get. At scale.

é€šè¿‡è§„æ¨¡åŒ–åœ°ç»™äºˆç¤¾ä¼šæ‰€éœ€è¦ï¼Œä½†è¿˜ä¸çŸ¥é“å¦‚ä½•å¾—åˆ°çš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œä½ ä¼šå˜å¾—å¯Œæœ‰ã€‚

Pick an industry where you can play long term games with long term people.

é€‰å–ä¸€ä¸ªä½ å¯ä»¥å’Œâ€œé•¿æœŸçš„äººâ€è¿›è¡Œâ€œé•¿æœŸæ¸¸æˆâ€çš„è¡Œä¸šã€‚

The Internet has massively broadened the possible space of careers. Most people havenâ€™t figured this out yet.

Play iterated games. All the returns in life, whether in wealth, relationships, or knowledge, come from compound interest.

è¿›è¡Œé‡å¤åšå¼ˆã€‚æ— è®ºæ˜¯è´¢å¯Œï¼Œå…³ç³»è¿˜æ˜¯çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œç”Ÿæ´»ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰çš„å›æŠ¥éƒ½æ¥è‡ªäºå¤åˆ©ã€‚

Pick business partners with high intelligence, energy, and, above all, integrity.

é€‰æ‹©é«˜åº¦èªæ˜ï¼Œæœ‰èƒ½é‡çš„ï¼Œä»¥åŠæ­£ç›´è¿™ä¸€é«˜äºæ‰€æœ‰å…¶å®ƒå› ç´ çš„äººï¼Œä½œä¸ºå•†ä¸šä¼™ä¼´ã€‚

Donâ€™t partner with cynics and pessimists. Their beliefs are self-fulfilling.

ä¸è¦å’Œæ„¤ä¸–å«‰ä¿—è€…ä»¥åŠæ‚²è§‚ä¸»ä¹‰è€…åˆä¼™ï¼Œä»–ä»¬çš„ä¿¡å¿µä¼šè‡ªæˆ‘å®ç°çš„ã€‚

Learn to sell. Learn to build. If you can do both, you will be unstoppable.

å­¦ä¹ é”€å”®ï¼Œå­¦ä¹ åˆ›å»ºã€‚å¦‚æœä¸¤ä¸ªä½ éƒ½èƒ½åšï¼Œä½ æ˜¯ä¸å¯é˜»æŒ¡çš„ã€‚

Arm yourself with specific knowledge, accountability, and leverage.

ç”¨â€œç‰¹ç§çŸ¥è¯†â€ï¼Œâ€œé å¾—ä½â€ï¼Œä»¥åŠâ€œå½±å“åŠ›â€æ¥æ­¦è£…ä½ è‡ªå·±ã€‚

Specific knowledge is knowledge that you cannot be trained for. If society can train you, it can train someone else, and replace you.

â€œç‰¹ç§çŸ¥è¯†â€æ˜¯ä½ ä¸èƒ½é€šè¿‡åŸ¹è®­å¾—åˆ°çš„çŸ¥è¯†ã€‚å¦‚æœç¤¾ä¼šå¯ä»¥åŸ¹è®­ä½ ï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥åŸ¹è®­å…¶ä»–äººæ¥å–ä»£ä½ ã€‚

â€œç‰¹ç§çŸ¥è¯†â€æ˜¯é€šè¿‡è¿½æ±‚ä½ çœŸæ­£çš„å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå’Œæ¿€æƒ…ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ç°åœ¨çƒ­é—¨çš„ä¸œè¥¿è¢«æ‰¾åˆ°çš„ã€‚

When specific knowledge is taught, itâ€™s through apprenticeships, not schools.

â€œç‰¹ç§çŸ¥è¯†â€æ˜¯é€šè¿‡å­¦å¾’åˆ¶ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯å­¦æ ¡è¢«æ•™ä¼šçš„ã€‚

Specific knowledge is often highly technical or creative. It cannot be outsourced or automated.

â€œç‰¹ç§çŸ¥è¯†â€é€šå¸¸æ˜¯æœ‰ç€é«˜åº¦æŠ€æœ¯æ€§æˆ–è€…åˆ›é€ æ€§çš„ï¼Œå®ƒä¸èƒ½è¢«å¤–åŒ…å‡ºå»æˆ–è€…è¢«è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æ‰ã€‚

Embrace accountability, and take business risks under your own name. Society will reward you with responsibility, equity, and leverage.

æ‹¥æŠ±é—®è´£ï¼Œå¹¶æŠŠå•†ä¸šé£é™©æ”¾åœ¨ä½ è‡ªå·±çš„åä¸‹ã€‚ç¤¾ä¼šä¼šä»¥è´£ä»»ï¼Œèµ„äº§å’Œå½±å“åŠ›æ¥å›æŠ¥ä½ ã€‚

The most accountable people have singular, public, and risky brands: Oprah, Trump, Kanye, Elon.

æœ€é å¾—ä½çš„äººæœ‰ç€å¥‡å¼‚åœ°ï¼Œå…¬å¼€çš„ï¼Œå†’é™©æ€§çš„å“ç‰Œï¼šå¥¥æ™®æ‹‰ï¼Œå·æ™®ï¼Œå‡¯æ©ï¼Œé©¬æ–¯å…‹

â€œGive me a lever long enough, and a place to stand, and I will move the earth.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠArchimedes

â€œç»™æˆ‘ä¸€ä¸ªè¶³å¤Ÿé•¿çš„æ æ†ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªç«‹è¶³ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±å¯ä»¥æ’¬åŠ¨åœ°çƒâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€” é˜¿åŸºç±³å¾·

Fortunes require leverage. Business leverage comes from capital, people, and products with no marginal cost of replication (code and media).

è´¢å¯Œéœ€è¦æ æ†ï¼Œå•†ä¸šæ æ†æ¥è‡ªäºèµ„æœ¬ï¼Œäººä»¥åŠæ²¡æœ‰è¾¹é™…æˆæœ¬å°±å¯ä»¥å¤åˆ¶çš„äº§å“ï¼ˆä»£ç å’Œåª’ä½“ï¼‰ã€‚

Capital means money. To raise money, apply your specific knowledge, with accountability, and show resulting good judgment.

èµ„æœ¬æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯é’±ã€‚ç”¨ä¸Šä½ çš„ç‰¹ç§çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œæ‰¿æ‹…è´£ä»»ï¼Œå¹¶å±•ç¤ºå‡ºå¥½çš„åˆ¤æ–­åŠ›æ¥å‹Ÿé›†é’±ã€‚

Labor means people working for you. Itâ€™s the oldest and most fought-over form of leverage. Labor leverage will impress your parents, but donâ€™t waste your life chasing it.

åŠ³åŠ¨åŠ›æ˜¯ä¸ºä½ å·¥ä½œçš„äººã€‚è¿™æ˜¯æœ€å¤è€çš„ï¼Œä»¥åŠæœ€å…·äº‰è®®çš„æ æ†å½¢å¼ã€‚åŠ³åŠ¨åŠ›æ æ†ä¼šè®©ä½ çš„çˆ¶æ¯ç•™ä¸‹æ·±åˆ»å°è±¡ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä¸è¦æµªè´¹ä½ çš„ç”Ÿå‘½æ¥è¿½é€å®ƒã€‚

Capital and labor are permissioned leverage. Everyone is chasing capital, but someone has to give it to you. Everyone is trying to lead, but someone has to follow you.

èµ„æœ¬å’ŒåŠ³åŠ¨åŠ›éƒ½æ˜¯éœ€è¦åˆ«äººå…è®¸çš„æ æ†ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½åœ¨è¿½é€èµ„æœ¬ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯éœ€è¦æœ‰æŸä¸ªäººæŠŠå®ƒç»™ä½ ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½åœ¨å°è¯•é¢†å¯¼ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯éœ€è¦æœ‰æŸä¸ªäººæ¥è¿½éšä½ ã€‚

Code and media are permissionless leverage. Theyâ€™re the leverage behind the newly rich. You can create software and media that works for you while you sleep.

ä»£ç å’Œåª’ä½“æ˜¯æ— éœ€åˆ«äººå…è®¸çš„æ æ†ã€‚å®ƒä»¬æ˜¯â€œæ–°å¯Œâ€ä»¬èƒŒåçš„æ æ†ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡åˆ›é€ è½¯ä»¶å’Œåª’ä½“å†…å®¹ï¼Œè®©å®ƒä»¬åœ¨ä½ ç¡è§‰çš„æ—¶å€™ä»ç„¶ä¸ºä½ å·¥ä½œã€‚

An army of robots is freely availableâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s just packed in data centers for heat and space efficiency. Use it.

æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæœºå™¨äººå¤§å†›å¯ä»¥å…è´¹å¾—åˆ°â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€” å®ƒåªæ˜¯å› ä¸ºéœ€è¦æ•£çƒ­å’Œå¤ªå åœ°æ–¹è€Œè¢«æ”¾åœ¨æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒé‡Œäº†ï¼ŒæŠŠå®ƒä»¬ç”¨èµ·æ¥ã€‚

If you canâ€™t code, write books and blogs, record videos and podcasts.

å¦‚æœä½ ä¸ä¼šå†™ä»£ç ï¼Œå†™ä¹¦æˆ–è€…åšå®¢ï¼Œå½•åˆ¶è§†é¢‘æˆ–è€…æ’­å®¢ã€‚

Leverage is a force multiplier for your judgement.

å½±å“åŠ›æ˜¯ä½ çš„åˆ¤æ–­åŠ›çš„åŠ›é‡ä¹˜æ•°ã€‚

Judgement requires experience, but can be built faster by learning foundational skills.

åˆ¤æ–­åŠ›éœ€è¦ç»éªŒï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡å­¦ä¹ åŸºç¡€æŠ€èƒ½æ›´å¿«åœ°å»ºç«‹ã€‚

å­¦ä¹ å¾®è§‚ç»æµå­¦ï¼Œåšå¼ˆè®ºï¼Œå¿ƒç†å­¦ï¼Œè¯´æœåŠ›ï¼Œä¼¦ç†å­¦ï¼Œæ•°å­¦ä»¥åŠè®¡ç®—æœºã€‚

Reading is faster than listening. Doing is faster than watching.

è¯»æ¯”å¬å¿«ï¼Œåšæ¯”çœ‹å¿«ã€‚

ä½ åº”è¯¥å¿™å¾—æ²¡ç©ºâ€œå–ä¸ªå’–å•¡â€ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä»ç„¶èƒ½å¤Ÿä¿æŒä¸è®©æ—¥ç¨‹è¡¨æ”¯ç¦»ç ´ç¢ã€‚

Set and enforce an aspirational personal hourly rate. If fixing a problem will save less than your hourly rate, ignore it. If outsourcing a task will cost less than your hourly rate, outsource it.

è®¾ç«‹å¹¶å¼ºåˆ¶å®æ–½ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰é›„å¿ƒçš„ä¸ªäººæ—¶è–ªã€‚å¦‚æœè§£å†³ä¸€ä¸ªé—®é¢˜èƒ½å¤Ÿçœä¸‹çš„ä½äºä½ çš„æ—¶è–ªï¼Œå¿½è§†å®ƒã€‚å¦‚æœå¤–åŒ…ä¸€ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡çš„æˆæœ¬ä½äºä½ çš„æ—¶è–ªï¼Œå¤–åŒ…æ‰ã€‚

entry.title: æ›´æ–°æ—¥å¿—å‚è€ƒæ ·å¼
entry.content:
Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on Keep a Changelog,
and this project adheres to Semantic Versioning.

Unreleased

1.0.0 - 2017-06-20

Added

  • New visual identity by @tylerfortune8.
  • Version navigation.
  • Links to latest released version in previous versions.
  • â€œWhy keep a changelog?â€ section.
  • â€œWho needs a changelog?â€ section.
  • â€œHow do I make a changelog?â€ section.
  • â€œFrequently Asked Questionsâ€ section.
  • New â€œGuiding Principlesâ€ sub-section to â€œHow do I make a changelog?â€.
  • Simplified and Traditional Chinese translations from @tianshuo.
  • German translation from @mpbzh & @Art4.
  • Italian translation from @azkidenz.
  • Swedish translation from @magol.
  • Turkish translation from @karalamalar.
  • French translation from @zapashcanon.
  • Brazilian Portugese translation from @Webysther.
  • Polish translation from @amielucha & @m-aciek.
  • Russian translation from @aishek.
  • Czech translation from @h4vry.
  • Slovak translation from @jkostolansky.
  • Korean translation from @pierceh89.
  • Croatian translation from @porx.
  • Persian translation from @Hameds.
  • Ukrainian translation from @osadchyi-s.

Changed

  • Start using â€œchangelogâ€ over â€œchange logâ€ since itâ€™s the common usage.
  • Start versioning based on the current English version at 0.3.0 to help
    translation authors keep things up-to-date.
  • Rewrite â€œWhat makes unicorns cry?â€ section.
  • Rewrite â€œIgnoring Deprecationsâ€ sub-section to clarify the ideal
    scenario.
  • Improve â€œCommit log diffsâ€ sub-section to further argument against
    them.
  • Merge â€œWhy canâ€™t people just use a git log diff?â€ with â€œCommit log
    diffsâ€
  • Fix typos in Simplified Chinese and Traditional Chinese translations.
  • Fix typos in Brazilian Portuguese translation.
  • Fix typos in Turkish translation.
  • Fix typos in Czech translation.
  • Fix typos in Swedish translation.
  • Improve phrasing in French translation.
  • Fix phrasing and spelling in German translation.

Removed

  • Section about â€œchangelogâ€ vs â€œCHANGELOGâ€.

0.3.0 - 2015-12-03

Added

  • RU translation from @aishek.
  • pt-BR translation from @tallesl.
  • es-ES translation from @ZeliosAriex.

0.2.0 - 2015-10-06

Changed

  • Remove exclusionary mentions of â€œopen sourceâ€ since this project can
    benefit both â€œopenâ€ and â€œclosedâ€ source projects equally.

0.1.0 - 2015-10-06

Added

  • Answer â€œShould you ever rewrite a change log?â€.

Changed

  • Improve argument against commit logs.
  • Start following SemVer properly.

0.0.8 - 2015-02-17

Changed

  • Update year to match in every README example.
  • Reluctantly stop making fun of Brits only, since most of the world
    writes dates in a strange way.

Fixed

  • Fix typos in recent README changes.
  • Update outdated unreleased diff link.

0.0.7 - 2015-02-16

Added

  • Link, and make it obvious that date format is ISO 8601.

Changed

  • Clarified the section on â€œIs there a standard change log format?â€.

Fixed

  • Fix Markdown links to tag comparison URL with footnote-style links.

0.0.6 - 2014-12-12

Added

  • README section on â€œyankedâ€ releases.

0.0.5 - 2014-08-09

Added

  • Markdown links to version tags on release headings.
  • Unreleased section to gather unreleased changes and encourage note
    keeping prior to releases.

0.0.4 - 2014-08-09

Added

  • Better explanation of the difference between the file (â€œCHANGELOGâ€)
    and its function â€œthe change logâ€.

Changed

  • Refer to a â€œchange logâ€ instead of a â€œCHANGELOGâ€ throughout the site
    to differentiate between the file and the purpose of the file â€” the
    logging of changes.

Removed

  • Remove empty sections from CHANGELOG, they occupy too much space and
    create too much noise in the file. People will have to assume that the
    missing sections were intentionally left out because they contained no
    notable changes.

0.0.3 - 2014-08-09

Added

  • â€œWhy should I care?â€ section mentioning The Changelog podcast.

0.0.2 - 2014-07-10

Added

  • Explanation of the recommended reverse chronological release ordering.

0.0.1 - 2014-05-31

Added

  • This CHANGELOG file to hopefully serve as an evolving example of a
    standardized open source project CHANGELOG.
  • CNAME file to enable GitHub Pages custom domain
  • README now contains answers to common questions about CHANGELOGs
  • Good examples and basic guidelines, including proper date formatting.
  • Counter-examples: â€œWhat makes unicorns cry?â€

entry.content:
